questions.question_text: What is the function of the fabric control plane node in a Cisco SD-Access deployment?

discussion.content:
C.
The control plane node’s database tracks all endpoints in the fabric site and associates the endpoints to fabric nodes, decoupling the endpoint IP address or MAC address from the location (closest router) in the network.
And this DB is known as Host Tracking Database (HTDB) - holds EID to RLOC bindings

Selected Answer: C
From the OCG:
A fabric control plane node is a LISP map server/resolver
(MS/MR) with enhanced functions for SD-Access, such as
fabric wireless and SGT mapping. It maintains a simple host
tracking database to map EIDs to RLOCs.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

The fabric control plane node is responsible for maintaining a comprehensive database of all endpoints and networks within the fabric. 
This database helps in facilitating endpoint identity and location services, allowing for efficient forwarding and policy enforcement within the SD-Access fabric.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct
C is Correct

Ref: Cisco SD Access - Connecting to the Data Center, Firewall, WAN and More!

“…
Cisco SD Access

Fabric Roles & Terminology
…
• Control-Plane Nodes – Map System that manages Endpoint to Device relationships
…”

A. It is responsible for policy application and network segmentation in the fabric.

Wrong answer.

B. It performs traffic encapsulation and security profiles enforcement in the fabric.

Wrong answer.

C. It holds a comprehensive database that tracks endpoints and networks in the fabric.

Correct answer.

D. It provides integration with legacy nonfabric-enabled environments.

Wrong answer.

Selected Answer: C
Fabric based on LISP Control Plane.

Selected Answer: C
voting. provided answer is correct.
Provided answer is correct

choices.B: It performs traffic encapsulation and security profiles enforcement in the fabric.
choices.C: It holds a comprehensive database that tracks endpoints and networks in the fabric.
choices.A: It is responsible for policy application and network segmentation in the fabric.
choices.D: It provides integration with legacy nonfabric-enabled environments.

discussion.content:

The forwarding table is created in advance.

PS:

ADMIN please fix that. Thank you!

comments.content: Answers like this really show that some of these questions are really off

discussion.content:
(CEF) Cisco Express Forwarding (also known as topology based switching):

 Forwarding table created in hardware beforehand. All packets will be switched using hardware. This is the fastest method but there are some limitations. Multilayer switches and routers use CEF.

Process switching:

 All packets are examined by the CPU and all forwarding decisions are made in software…very slow!

given answer is incorrect

Cisco Express Forwarding:
- The forwarding table is created in advance
- All packets are switched using hardware


Process Switching:
- The router processor is involved with every forwarding decision
- All forwarding decisions are made in software


-CEF builds a forwarding table (FIB) in advance, which contains precomputed next-hop information for efficient packet forwarding.
-CEF leverages hardware-based switching such as ASICs in (Purpose-Made) to forward packets quickly and efficiently.

-In process switching, the router’s main CPU (router processor) is directly involved in making forwarding decisions for each packet.
-Process s´Switching relies entirely on software-based forwarding decisions
Correct

comments.content: sorry i misread it, answer is incorrect

discussion.content:
So many easy questions with wrong answers, people screaming in the comments to change answers, not only you don't do that, but you also have the audacity to ask $200 for 3 months access.
Not to mention the "100% free" label.
CEF all packet are switched using Hardware
Interestingly two of the blocks are practically saying the same thing

There are different switching methods to forward IP packets. Here are the different switching options:

Process switching:
All packets are examined by the CPU and all forwarding decisions are made in software…very slow!
Fast switching (also known as route caching):
The first packet in a flow is examined by the CPU; the forwarding decision is cached in hardware for the next packets in the same flow. This is a faster method.
(CEF) Cisco Express Forwarding (also known as topology based switching):
Forwarding table created in hardware beforehand. All packets will be switched using hardware. This is the fastest method but there are some limitations. Multilayer switches and routers use CEF.
https://safe.menlosecurity.com/https://networklessons.com/switching/cef-cisco-express-forwarding
cef support both software and hardware.

CEF - software

PS - hardware

CEF makes en hardware : https://networklessons.com/switching/cef-cisco-express-forwarding
I think CEF makes the forwarding decisions in hardware.

Selected Answer: BD
B and D. EIGRP has faster convergence time than OSPF because EIGRP has a backup route (feasible successor) readily available. OSPF would have to first signal with LSAs, then run SPF calculation, then update the RIB and the FIB.

Selected Answer: BD
EIGRP:
Uses DUAL for fast convergence.
Hybrid protocol with features of both link-state and distance-vector.
Supports a maximum of 255 hops.
Supports equal and unequal load balancing.

OSPF:
Link-state protocol.
Does not use hop count; supports unlimited hops based on link cost.
Supports only equal-cost load balancing.

Selected Answer: BD
B and D are correct

comments.content:
EIGRP has a default maximum hop count limit of 100, which can be configured up to a maximum of 255.

A is incorrect because EIGRP can provide a shorter convergence time with minimal network traffic.

https://notes.networklessons.com/eigrp-hop-count#:~:text=EIGRP%20has%20a%20default%20maximum,maintain%20network%20stability%20and%20manageability.

https://community.fs.com/article/eigrp-vs-ospf-differences.html#:~:text=EIGRP%20can%20provide%20a%20shorter%20convergence%20time%20with%20minimal%20network%20traffic

choices.A: OSPF provides shorter convergence time than EIGRP.
choices.D: OSPF supports an unlimited number of hops EIGRP supports a maximum of 255 hops.
choices.B: OSPF supports only equal-cost load balancing EIGRP supports unequal-cost load balancing.
choices.E: OSPF supports unequal-cost load balancing EIGRP supports only equal-cost load balancing.
choices.C: OSPF is distance vector protocol. EIGRP is a link-state protocol.

questions.question_text:

Refer to the exhibit. A network engineer must configure the router to use the ISE-Servers group for authentication. If both ISE servers are unavailable, the local username database must be used. If no usernames are defined in the configuration, then the enable password must be the last resort to log in. Which configuration must be applied to achieve this result?
When using BFD in a network design, which consideration must be made?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
D is wrong.... from https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/12_0s/feature/guide/fs_bfd.html#wp1043332
"Because some parts of BFD can be distributed to the data plane, it can be less CPU-intensive than the reduced EIGRP, IS-IS, and OSPF timers, which exist wholly at the control plane."
BFD is often done directly at the NIC level and reduces CPU usage compared to things like SLA monitoring.

Selected Answer: A
We use BFD with BGP to provide fast routing reconvergence.

D is the correct option, since you can achieve subsecond without BDF

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The answer is A. We use BFD with BGP to provide fast routing reconvergence. 
A. BFD is used with dynamic routing protocols to provide subsecond convergence.

Selected Answer: D
Provided answer is correct.

choices.A: BFD is used with dynamic routing protocols to provide subsecond convergence.
choices.C: BFD is used with NSF and graceful to provide subsecond convergence.
choices.D: BFD is more CPU-intensive than using reduced hold timers with routing protocols.
choices.B: BFD is used with first hop routing protocols to provide subsecond convergence.
